{{Infobox person |image = Replace this image female.svg |image_size = 150px |name = Ayala Zacks-Abramov
אילה זקס-אברמוב |caption = |birth_date = 1912 |birth_place = [[Jerusalem]], [[Mandatory Palestine|British Mandate for Palestine]] (now [[Israel]]) |death_date = August 30, 2011 |death_place = [[Israel]] |occupation = [[art collector]] |children = |nationality = [[Israelis|Israeli]]
[[Canadians|Canadian]] }} '''Ayala Zacks-Abramov''' ({{lang-he|אילה זקס-אברמוב}}, 1912 – 30 August 2011) was an [[Israel]]i-[[Canadians|Canadian]][http://www.artlyst.com/articles/canadas-peggy-guggenheim-ayala-zacksabramov-dies Canada's Peggy Guggenheim Ayala Zacks-Abramov Dies - ArtLyst] [[art collector]]. Ayala was widowed three times, and was previously married to the Canadian art collector Samuel Jacob Zacks and to the knesset member [[Zalman Abramov]]. ==Biography== Zacks-Abramov was born in Jerusalem in 1912 as Ayala Ben-Tovim. Her parents, Shmuel Ben-Tovim and Rashe (née: Berman) were married in Jerusalem in 1902. She studied in London and in Paris where she met her first husband, Morris Fleg, whom she married in 1938. In 1940, during [[World War II]], he joined the [[French Resistance]] after Fleg enlisted to the army and was killed during a military operation. In 1947, she married Samuel Zacks, a Canadian economist and art collector, whom she met during her stay in [[Switzerland]]. After marrying, the couple began to collect art items from the 19th century and the 20th century, mainly of French, Canadian and Israeli artists such as [[Gauguin]], [[Auguste Rodin|Rodin]], [[Picasso]], [[Henri Matisse]], [[Wassily Kandinsky|Kandinsky]] and [[Chagall]]. They also acquired art by Israeli artists such as [[Marcel Janco]], [[Mordechai Ardon]], [[Reuven Rubin]] and [[Anna Ticho]], and art of relatively unknown artists at the time of the purchase such as [[Ofer Lellouche]], [[Yigal Tumarkin]] and [[Joseph Zaritsky]]. In 1970, her husband Zacks died. She returned to Israel in 1976 and married Zalman Abramov, who was a lawyer and a Knesset member.[http://www.haaretz.co.il/gallery/1.1373523 מתה פטרונית האמנות אילה זקס אברמוב - גלריה - הארץ] The couple were [[Patronage|patrons of the arts]], and Abramov continued to support the art world even after her husband's death in 1997. Zachs-Abramov supported over the years the [[Tel Aviv Museum of Art]] and the [[Israel Museum]] and had a hand in their growth. Both the museums have halls named after her. She mentioned these museums in her will, in which she declared that her art collection would be divided between them. The Israeli notable painter [[Joseph Zaritsky]] painted a well-known figurative portrait of her. Many of the art works in Zachs-Abramov's possession were donated or loaned through to years to museums in Israel, France and Canada. ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://www.artlyst.com/articles/canadas-peggy-guggenheim-ayala-zacksabramov-dies Canada's Peggy Guggenheim Ayala Zacks-Abramov Dies] - published on artlyst.com * [http://www.haaretz.co.il/gallery/1.1373523 The art patron Ayala Zacks Abramov died] - published on [[Haaretz]] on August 30, 2011 {{he icon}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Zacks-Abramov, Ayala}} [[Category:1912 births]] [[Category:2011 deaths]] [[Category:Israeli art collectors]] [[Category:Israeli art]] [[Category:Burials at the Jewish cemetery on the Mount of Olives]]

{{speciesbox |image = Cannabis sativa 2.jpg |image_caption = ''Cannabis sativa'' female- recreational/medicinal marijuana, not hemp |genus = Cannabis |species = sativa |authority = [[Carl Linnaeus|L.]] |subdivision_ranks = [[Subspecies]] |subdivision = *''C. sativa'' ssp. ''sativa'' *[[Cannabis indica|''C. sativa'' ssp. ''indica'']] *[[Cannabis ruderalis|''C. sativa'' ssp. ''ruderalis'']] }} {{Cannabis sidebar}} [[File:Cannabis sativa 1.jpg|thumb|left|Male ''Cannabis sativa'' in flower]] '''''Cannabis sativa''''' is an annual [[Herbaceous plant|herbaceous]] [[flowering plant]] indigenous to eastern Asia but now of cosmopolitan distribution due to widespread cultivation.<ref name="FlorianKronkright1991">{{cite book|author1=Mary-Lou E. Florian|author2=Dale Paul Kronkright|author3=Ruth E. Norton|title=The Conservation of Artifacts Made from Plant Materials|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Vp5OAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA49|date=21 March 1991|publisher=Getty Publications|isbn=978-0-89236-160-1|pages=49–}}</ref> It has been cultivated throughout [[recorded history]], used as a source of [[Hemp#fibre|industrial fiber]], [[Hemp oil|seed oil]], [[Hempnut|food]], [[Cannabis (drug)|recreation]], [[entheogenic use of cannabis|religious and spiritual moods]] and [[Medical cannabis|medicine]]. Each part of the plant is harvested differently, depending on the purpose of its use. The species was first classified by [[Carl Linnaeus]] in 1753.<ref>Greg Green, ''The Cannabis Breeder's Bible'', Green Candy Press, 2005, pp. 15-16 {{ISBN|9781931160278}}</ref>
==Plant physiology== {{main|Cannabis|Cannabis cultivation}} <!--- needs resynch ---> The flowers of ''Cannabis sativa'' are unisexual and plants are most often either male or female.<ref name="SHARMA2011">{{cite book|author=SHARMA|title=PLANT TAXONOMY 2E|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Roi0lwSXFnUC&pg=PA459|year=2011|publisher=Tata McGraw-Hill Education|isbn=978-1-259-08137-8|pages=459–}}</ref> It is a short-day flowering plant, with staminate (male) plants usually taller and less robust than pistillate (female or male) plants<ref>.http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=200006342</ref> The [[flower]]s of the female plant are arranged in [[raceme]]s and can produce hundreds of seeds. Male plants shed their pollen and die several weeks prior to seed ripening on the female plants. Under typical conditions with a light period of 12 to 14 hours both sexes are produced in equal numbers because of heritable [[XY sex-determination system|X and Y chromosomes]].<ref name="ClarkeMerlin2013">{{cite book|author1=Robert Clarke|author2=Mark Merlin|title=Cannabis: Evolution and Ethnobotany|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=poenY6QMq8UC&pg=PA16|date=1 September 2013|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-95457-1|pages=16–}}</ref> Although genetic factors dispose a plant to become male or female, environmental factors including the [[Diurnal cycle|diurnal light cycle]] can alter sexual expression.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Schaffner|first=John H.|date=1921-01-01|title=Influence of Environment on Sexual Expression in Hemp|journal=Botanical Gazette|volume=71|issue=3|pages=197–219|doi=10.1086/332818|jstor=2469863}}</ref> Naturally occurring [[monoecious]] plants, with both male and female parts, are either sterile or fertile but artificially induced "[[hermaphrodites]]" can have fully functional reproductive organs. "Feminized" seed sold by many commercial seed suppliers are derived from artificially "hermaphrodytic" females that lack the male gene, or by treating the plants with hormones or silver [[thiosulfate]].
==Pharmacology== {{main|Cannabis (drug)}} [[File:Tetrahydrocannabinol.svg|thumb|left|200px|Δ<sup>9</sup>-[[tetrahydrocannabinol]] (THC)]] [[File:Cannabis sativa Koehler drawing.jpg|thumb|right|''Cannabis sativa'', scientific drawing from ''c''1900]]
Although the main [[psychoactive]] constituent of ''Cannabis'' is [[tetrahydrocannabinol]] (THC), the plant is known to contain more than 500 compounds, among them at least 113 [[cannabinoid]]s; however, most of these "minor" cannabinoids are only produced in trace amounts.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Aizpurua-Olaizola|first=Oier|last2=Soydaner|first2=Umut|last3=Öztürk|first3=Ekin|last4=Schibano|first4=Daniele|last5=Simsir|first5=Yilmaz|last6=Navarro|first6=Patricia|last7=Etxebarria|first7=Nestor|last8=Usobiaga|first8=Aresatz|date=2016-02-02|title=Evolution of the Cannabinoid and Terpene Content during the Growth ofCannabis sativaPlants from Different Chemotypes|journal=Journal of Natural Products|language=EN|volume=79|issue=2|pages=324–331|doi=10.1021/acs.jnatprod.5b00949|pmid=26836472}}</ref> Besides THC, another cannabinoid produced in high concentrations by some plants is [[cannabidiol]] (CBD), which is not psychoactive but has recently been shown to block the effect of THC in the nervous system.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Russo|first=Ethan B|date=2011-08-01|title=Taming THC: potential cannabis synergy and phytocannabinoid-terpenoid entourage effects|journal=British Journal of Pharmacology|language=en|volume=163|issue=7|pages=1344–1364|doi=10.1111/j.1476-5381.2011.01238.x|issn=1476-5381|pmc=3165946|pmid=21749363}}</ref> Differences in the chemical composition of ''Cannabis'' varieties may produce different effects in humans. Synthetic THC, called [[dronabinol]], does not contain cannabidiol (CBD), [[cannabinol]] (CBN), or other cannabinoids, which is one reason why its [[Pharmacology|pharmacological]] effects may differ significantly from those of natural ''Cannabis'' preparations.
==Chemical constituents== ''Beside cannabinoids, Cannabis'' chemical constituents include about 120 compounds responsible for its [[Cannabis flower essential oil|characteristic aroma]]. These are mainly volatile [[terpene]]s and [[sesquiterpene]]s. * α-[[Pinene]]<ref name=essential>{{cite journal |doi=10.1002/ffj.993 |title=Essential oils of different cultivars of ''Cannabis sativa'' L. and their antimicrobial activity |year=2001 |vauthors=Novak J, Zitterl-Eglseer K, Deans SG, Franz CM |journal=Flavour and Fragrance Journal |volume=16 |issue=4 |pages=259–262}}</ref> * [[Myrcene]]<ref name=essential/> * [[Linalool]]<ref name=essential/> * [[Limonene]]<ref name=essential/> * Trans-β-[[ocimene]]<ref name=essential/> * α-[[Terpinolene]]<ref name=essential/> * Trans-[[caryophyllene]]<ref name=essential/> * α-[[Humulene]],<ref name=essential/> contributes to the characteristic aroma of ''Cannabis sativa'' * [[Caryophyllene]],<ref name=essential/> with which some hashish detection dogs are trained<ref>[http://www.bojensen.net/EssentialOilsEng/EssentialOils13A/EssentialOils13A.htm Essential Oils]</ref>
===Difference between ''C. sativa'' and ''C. indica''=== Human intervention has produced variation within the species and some authorities only recognize one species in the genus that has had divergent selective pressure to either produce plants with more fiber or plants with greater THC content.<ref name="ChandraLata2017">{{cite book|author1=Suman Chandra|author2=Hemant Lata|author3=Mahmoud A. ElSohly|title=Cannabis sativa L. - Botany and Biotechnology|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yfokDwAAQBAJ&pg=PA54|date=23 May 2017|publisher=Springer|isbn=978-3-319-54564-6|pages=54–}}</ref> Large variability exists within either species, and there is an expanding discussion whether the existing paradigm used to differentiate species adequately represents the variability found within the genus ''Cannabis''.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Piomelli|first=Daniele|last2=Russo|first2=Ethan B.|date=2016-01-14|title=The Cannabis sativa Versus Cannabis indica Debate: An Interview with Ethan Russo, MD|journal=Cannabis and Cannabinoid Research|volume=1|issue=1|pages=44–46|doi=10.1089/can.2015.29003.ebr|pmid=28861479|pmc=5576603}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Aizpurua-ppOlaizola|first=Oier|last2=Omar|first2=Jone|last3=Navarro|first3=Patricia|last4=Olivares|first4=Maitane|last5=Etxebarria|first5=Nestor|last6=Usobiaga|first6=Aresatz|date=2014-10-23|title=Identification and quantification of cannabinoids in Cannabis sativa L. plants by high performance liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry|journal=Analytical and Bioanalytical Chemistry|language=en|volume=406|issue=29|pages=7549–7560|doi=10.1007/s00216-014-8177-x|pmid=25338935|issn=1618-2642}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hazekamp|first=A.|last2=Fischedick|first2=J. T.|date=2012-07-01|title=Cannabis - from cultivar to chemovar|journal=Drug Testing and Analysis|language=en|volume=4|issue=7–8|pages=660–667|doi=10.1002/dta.407|pmid=22362625|issn=1942-7611}}</ref> There are five chemotaxonomic types of ''Cannabis'': one with high levels of THC, one which is more fibrous and has higher levels of CBD, one that is an intermediate between the two, another one with high levels of [[cannabigerol]] (CBG), and the last one almost without cannabinoids.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mandolino|first=Giuseppe|last2=Bagatta|first2=Manuela|last3=Carboni|first3=Andrea|last4=Ranalli|first4=Paolo|last5=Meijer|first5=Etienne de|date=2003-03-01|title=Qualitative and Quantitative Aspects of the Inheritance of Chemical Phenotype in Cannabis|journal=Journal of Industrial Hemp|volume=8|issue=2|pages=51–72|doi=10.1300/J237v08n02_04|issn=1537-7881}}</ref>
''Cannabis'' strains with relatively high CBD:THC ratios are less likely to induce [[anxiety]] than vice versa.<ref name="RussoTyler2015">{{cite book|author1=Ethan B Russo|author2=Virginia M Tyler|title=Handbook of Psychotropic Herbs: A Scientific Analysis of Herbal Remedies for Psychiatric Conditions|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cZtACwAAQBAJ&pg=PT233|date=22 December 2015|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-136-38607-7|pages=233–}}</ref> This may be due to CBD's [[Receptor antagonist|antagonistic]] effects at the [[cannabinoid receptor]]s, compared to THC's [[partial agonist]] effect.<ref>2015. "Marijuana Chemicals Cannabinoids, Terpenes, Flavonoids (THC and CBD)." Howtogrowmarijuana.com. Retrieved from http://howtogrowmarijuana.com/cannabinoids-terpenes-flavonoids-cbd-thc/.</ref> CBD is also a [[5-HT1A receptor|5-HT<sub>1A</sub> receptor]] ([[serotonin]]) agonist, which may also contribute to an anxiolytic-content effect.<ref name="Joy-Watson-Benson">{{cite book |title=Marijuana and Medicine: Assessing The Science Base |author1=J.E. Joy |author2=S. J. Watson, Jr. |author3=J.A. Benson, Jr |location=Washington D.C |publisher=[[United States National Academy of Sciences|National Academy of Sciences Press]] |year=1999 |url=http://books.nap.edu/html/marimed/ |isbn=978-0-585-05800-9}}</ref> The effects of ''sativa'' are well known for its cerebral high, while ''indica'' is well known for its sedative effects which some prefer for night time use.<ref name="Joy-Watson-Benson"/> Both types are used as [[medical cannabis]]. ''Indica'' plants are normally shorter and stockier than ''sativas''.<ref name="Fischedick">{{cite journal|last2=Hazekamp|first2=Arno|last3=Erkelens|first3=Tjalling|last4=Choi|first4=Young Hae|last5=Verpoorte|first5=Rob|date=December 2010|title=Metabolic fingerprinting of Cannabis sativa L., cannabinoids and terpenoids for chemotaxonomic and drug standardization purposes|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S003194221000381X#|journal=Phytochemistry|volume=71|issue=17–18|pages=2058–2073|doi=10.1016/j.phytochem.2010.10.001|pmid=21040939|last1=Fischedick|first1=Justin Thomas|accessdate=28 May 2015}}</ref> They have broader, deeply serrated leaves and a compact and dense flower cluster.
==Common uses== {{main|Cannabis#Industrial and personal uses|l1=Industrial and personal uses of ''Cannabis''|Cannabis (drug)|Hemp}}
''Cannabis sativa'' seeds are chiefly used to make hempseed oil which can be used for cooking, lamps, lacquers or paints. They can also be used as caged-bird feed, as they provide a moderate source of nutrients for most birds. The flowers (and to a lesser extent the leaves, stems, and seeds) contain [[psychoactive]] [[chemical compound]]s known as [[cannabinoids]] that are consumed for recreational, medicinal and spiritual purposes. When so used, preparations of flowers ([[marijuana]]) and leaves and preparations derived from resinous extract (e.g., [[hashish]]) are consumed by smoking, vaporising and oral ingestion. Historically, [[tincture]]s, [[Herbal tea|teas]] and [[ointment]]s have also been common preparations. In [[traditional medicine]] of India in particular ''C. sativa'' has been used as hallucinogenic, hypnotic, [[sedative]], [[analgesic]] and [[anti-inflammatory]] agent.<ref>Bonini, Sara Anna. “Cannabis Sativa: A Comprehensive Ethnopharmacological Review of a Medicinal Plant with a Long History.” Shibboleth Authentication Request, ELSEVIER IRELAND LTD, Dec. 2017, apps.webofknowledge.com.proxy.cc.uic.edu/full_record.do?product=WOS&search_mode=GeneralSearch&qid=7&SID=5DN8tlmEqPYfoMJMbXL&page=1&doc=1.</ref> Cannabis sativa has been used in medical practices as a therapeutic alternative for people with mental illnesses to lift off stress which leads recreational users to believe that sativa can aid them with their stress heavy lives. However, recent ethnopharmacology studies have shown that sativa can actually cause sleep disorders and heighten neurological and psychiatric illness.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Wang | first1 = L | last2 = Waltenberger | first2 = B | last3 = Pferschy-Wenzig | first3 = EM | last4 = Blunder | first4 = M | last5 = Liu | first5 = X | last6 = Malainer | first6 = C | last7 = Blazevic | first7 = T | last8 = Schwaiger | first8 = S | last9 = Rollinger | first9 = JM | last10 = Heiss | first10 = EH | last11 = Schuster | first11 = D | last12 = Kopp | first12 = B | last13 = Bauer | first13 = R | last14 = Stuppner | first14 = H | last15 = Dirsch | first15 = VM | last16 = Atanasov | first16 = AG | year = 2014 | title = Natural product agonists of peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma (PPARγ): a review | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0006295214004249# | journal = Biochem Pharmacol | volume = 92| issue = 1| pages = 73–89| doi = 10.1016/j.bcp.2014.07.018 | pmid = 25083916 | pmc=4212005}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|date=2002-01-01|title=Characteristics of hemp (Cannabis sativa L.) seed oil|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S030881460100245X|journal=Food Chemistry|language=en|volume=76|issue=1|pages=33–43|doi=10.1016/S0308-8146(01)00245-X|issn=0308-8146}}</ref>
==Cultivation== A ''Cannabis'' plant in the vegetative growth phase of its life requires more than 12–13 hours of light per day to stay vegetative. Flowering usually occurs when darkness equals at least 12 hours per day{{Dubious|date=June 2015}}. The flowering cycle can last anywhere between nine and fifteen weeks, depending on the strain and environmental conditions.
In soil, the optimum [[pH]] for the plant is 6.3 to 6.8. In [[hydroponics|hydroponic]] growing, the nutrient solution is best at 5.2 to 5.8, making ''Cannabis'' well-suited to hydroponics because this pH range is hostile to most bacteria and fungi.
[[Tissue culture]] multiplication has become important in producing medically important clones,<ref name="Arora2010">{{cite book|author=Rajesh Arora|title=Medicinal Plant Biotechnology|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3sPwKo3b3cUC&pg=PA103|year=2010|publisher=CABI|isbn=978-1-84593-692-1|pages=103–}}</ref> while seed production remains the generally preferred means of multiplication.<ref name="ChandraLata2017"/>
==Cultivars== Broadly, there are three main [[cultivar|cultivar groups]] of cannabis that are cultivated today: * Cultivars primarily cultivated for their fibre, characterised by long stems and little branching. * Cultivars grown for seed which can be eaten entirely raw or from which [[hemp oil]] is extracted. * Cultivars grown for medicinal or [[recreational drug use|recreational]] purposes. A nominal if not legal distinction is often made between industrial hemp, with concentrations of psychoactive compounds far too low to be useful for that purpose, and [[marijuana]].

{{Infobox saint |name=Blessed Catherine of Racconigi |birth_date=1486 |birth_place=[[Piedmont]] |death_date=1574 |death_place=[[Racconigi]] |feast_day=4 September |venerated_in=[[Catholic Church]] |image= |imagesize= |caption=Image of Blessed Catherine |titles=Blessed |beatified_date= |beatified_place= |beatified_by= |canonized_date= |canonized_place= |canonized_by= |attributes= |patronage= |major_shrine= |suppressed_date= |issues= }}
'''Blessed''' '''Catherine of Racconigi, [[Third Order of St. Dominic|T.O.S.D.]]''', (1486 – 1574, [[Racconigi]]) was an [[Italian people|Italian]] member of the [[Third Order of St. Dominic]], who is recognized for being a [[mysticism|mystic]] and a [[stigmatic]].
==Biography== {{Christian mysticism}} Most of the information regarding Catherine Mattei is derived from a ''vita'' written by her friend, John Francis Pico, Prince of Mirandola.<ref name=rfo>[https://books.google.com/books?id=m67PAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA227&lpg=PA227&dq=Catherine+of+Racconigi&source=bl&ots=sPxD9LjD4z&sig=LWwYi0JmdU3-GZnYXC8Bq4O6hj8&hl=en&sa=X&ei=vl2WVO6cB4O-ggSfm4SYAg&ved=0CD4Q6AEwCjgK#v=onepage&q=Catherine%20of%20Racconigi&f=false O'Connor, R.F., "Blessed Catherine of Racconigi", ''The American Catholic Quarterly Review'', (James Andrew Corcoran, Patrick John Ryan, Edmond Francis Prendergast eds.), Volume 41, p.211, Hardy and Mahony, Philadelphia, 1916]</ref> Catherine Mattei ({{lang-it|Caterina Mattei}}) was born in the [[Piedmont]] region of [[Northwest Italy]] in 1487 into an impoverished household in the [[Province of Cuneo]]. Intermittent conflicts in the area brought widespread poverty. Her parents were Giorgio and Bilia de Ferrari Mattei. Her father was an unemployed tool-maker, while her mother was a [[weaver (occupation)|weaver]] who was able to support the family. Her father was often despondent<ref name=opwest>{{cite web|url=http://www.opwest.org/index.php/2011/09/Blessed-Catherine-Mattei|title=Full Article - Western Dominican Province|work=opwest.org|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141221084322/http://www.opwest.org/index.php/2011/09/Blessed-Catherine-Mattei|archivedate=2014-12-21|df=}}</ref> and quarrelsome, thus the family environment was usually one of conflict.
She is said to have had, at about the age of nine, a vision of Jesus, who appeared to her as a boy of about ten. She would also begin to have visions of other saints such as the [[Dominican order|Dominican]]s [[Catherine of Siena]] and [[Peter of Verona|Peter Martyr]]. The Virgin told her that Jesus wanted to have her as his Bride, as a token of which she was given a [[wedding ring]], which she had all her life—but which only she could see. She began to have frequent [[religious ecstasy|ecstasies]] and visions of Jesus, who always appeared to her as the same age she was at the time of the vision.
Many miracles would result from her visions: a broken dish was made whole again, and money and food would be provided when the family’s poverty was extreme. In times of trial she received great consolation from the aspiration, "Jesus, is my only hope!"<ref name=opwest/>
Blessed Catherine eventually joined the [[Dominican Order]] herself, but, like St. Catherine, she was opposed in this wish by her family. As a result, instead of entering a monastery of the [[cloister]]ed [[nun]]s of the Order, she became a [[Third Order of St. Dominic|tertiary]] of the Order, continuing to live with her family. As the visions increased she received the [[stigmata]], although, the wounds were not visible until after her death.<ref name=opwest/>
Her mystical experiences roused a storm of gossip among her neighbors, who were terrified at the lights and sounds that came from her home; even the Dominican [[friar]]s began to ostracize her. Eventually she was forced out of the town and settled in the city of Racconigi. During her lifetime, Catherine was sought for counsel and prayer. She would keep in her prayers in a special way the salvation of soldiers who were dying in battle.
==Veneration== Many miracles took place before and after her death and her detractors came to acknowledge the holiness of her life. Her [[cult (religious practice)|cult]] was approved in 1810 by Pope [[Pius VII]].
