[[File:Gian Lorenzo Bernini - Dove of the Holy Spirit.JPG|thumb|right|Dove of the Holy Spirit (ca. 1660, alabaster, Throne of St. Peter, St. Peter's Basilica, Vatican)]] '''Monastic silence''' is a spiritual practice recommended in a variety of religious traditions for purposes including facilitation of approaching deity, and achieving elevated states of spiritual purity.<ref name="Holytrinitymonastery.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.holytrinitymonastery.org/fr-benedict.html#Silence |title=Holy Trinity Monastery, a Benedictine Community in Southeastern Arizona, Chronicles |publisher=Holytrinitymonastery.org |date=2010-02-24 |accessdate=2011-06-07}}</ref> It may be in accordance with a monk's formal [[vow of silence]], but can also engage [[laity]] who have not taken vows, or novices who are preparing to take vows. Monastic silence is more highly developed in the Roman Catholic faith than in Protestantism, but it is not limited to Catholicism. The practice has a corresponding manifestation in the Orthodox church, which teaches that silence is a means to access the deity, to develop self-knowledge,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pravmir.com/the-value-of-silence/ |title=The Value of Silence - A Russian Orthodox Church Website : A Russian Orthodox Church Website |publisher=Pravmir.com |date=2011-03-28 |accessdate=2011-06-07}}</ref> or to live more harmoniously.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.orthodoxresearchinstitute.org/articles/misc/allen_silence_that_screams.htm |title=Silence That Screams |publisher=Orthodoxresearchinstitute.org |date= |accessdate=2011-06-07}}</ref> Theophilus, patriarch of Alexandria, placed the virtue of silence on par with the faith itself in a synodal letter from AD 400. "Monks—if they wish to be what they are called—will love silence and the Catholic faith, for nothing at all is more important than these two things." <ref>{{cite web|url=http://brepols.metapress.com/content/g557085012jl7501/ |title=Brepols Publishers - Journal Article |publisher=Brepols.metapress.com |date=2008-10-01 |accessdate=2011-06-07}}</ref>
==Practice of silence by ordained and laity == The practice of silence is observed during different parts of the day; practitioners talk when they need to but maintain a sense of silence or a sense of prayer when talking. The rules of silence apply to both vowed practitioners and non-vowed guests.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|last=Corrigan |first=Maureen |url=https://www.npr.org/2011/02/10/132708398/spare-and-sublime-a-monasterys-spell-of-silence#132737350 |title=Spare And Sublime: A Monastery's Spell Of 'Silence' |publisher=NPR |date=2011-02-10 |accessdate=2011-06-07}}</ref> Religious recommendations of silence as [[praxis (process)|praxis]] do not deprecate speech when it is thoughtful and considerate of commonly held values. According to Andrew March of the Benedictine order, we "can listen to substantive speech for hours while five minutes of garrulous speech is too much." It is noteworthy that "silence" can include what is more aptly characterized as "quietness", i.e. speaking in low voice tones.<ref name="autogenerated1"/> Silence is not an absence of words or thoughts—it is a positive and substantive reality.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
==Christian contemplative traditions==
===Old Testament roots=== In the book ''Silence, The Still Small Voice of God'', Andrew March establishes the roots of silence doctrine in the [[Psalms]] attributed to David. "Benedict and his monastics would know from chanting the Psalter every week the verse that follows: “I was silent and still; I held my peace to no avail; my distress grew worse, my heart became hot within me. While I mused, the fire burned; then I spoke with my tongue” (Psalm 39: 3).
St. Norbet's Arts Center<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.virtualmuseum.ca/Exhibitions/Trappist/english/ideas/silence.html |title=Trappist Monk : Ideas : Silence |publisher=Virtualmuseum.ca |date= |accessdate=2011-06-07}}</ref> also anchors its views on silence in the Old Testament: "For God alone my soul waits in silence; from him comes my salvation." (Psalm 62)
=== Aids to practice === The Trappist rubric "Living in silence" illustrates centuries-old hand gestures which were "developed to convey basic communication of work and spirit".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.virtualmuseum.ca/Exhibitions/Trappist/english/ideas/monasticism.html |title=Trappist monk : Ideas : Monasticism |publisher=Virtualmuseum.ca |date= |accessdate=2011-06-07}}</ref>
===Benedictine=== Silence plays a salient role in the [[Benedictine rule]]. It is thought that by clearing the mind of distraction, one may listen more attentively to the deity.
Christian theology differs from Dharmic religions with regard to the mode in which spiritual ascent transpires within the context of contemplative quiet. Buddhism and Hinduism promote various spiritual practices, as do many Christian denominations. However, Christianity, particularly Protestantism, emphasizes the belief that ultimate spiritual achievement is not within the grasp of mortals, no matter how persistent their practice may be. Rather, the mechanism of spiritual attainment, which they regard as salvation and proximity to the deity, is believed to occur solely through supernatural mechanism. This mechanism is variously described as the action of God, conceived as the Father, or by action of the Holy Spirit. This mechanism of action, whether conceptualized as the Father or the Spirit, is called ''grace''.
In contemplative practice, the role of silence is expressed by the Fr. David Bird, OSB, (Order of St. Benedict): "When both our interior and exterior are quiet, God will do the rest."
===Cistercian=== Cistercian monastics have remained active in the promotion of contemplative [[Christian meditation|meditation]].<ref name="Cistercian.org.au">{{cite web|url=http://www.cistercian.org.au/pages/monastic-silence.php |title=Tarrawarra Abbey - Monastic Silence |publisher=Cistercian.org.au |date=2007-05-22 |accessdate=2011-06-07}}</ref> Part of the emphasis is on achieving spiritual ascent, but monastic silence also functions to avoid sin.<ref name="Cistercian.org.au"/>
Although speech is morally neutral ''per se'', the Epistle of James (3:1-12) and writers of the monastic tradition see silence as the only effective means of neutralizing our tendency towards sins of the tongue.<ref name="Cistercian.org.au"/> There is an ongoing dialogue between Benedictine and Cistercian which speaks of a "monastic archetype" characterized by peace and silence.<ref>{{cite journal|publisher=Monastic Dialogue |url=http://monasticdialog.com/a.php?id=21 |title=Dialogue between Christian and Non-Christian Monks, Opportunities and Difficulties |last=Rossano |first=Pietro |volume=Bulletin 10 |date=February 1981 |accessdate=2012-01-25}}</ref>
===Trappist=== A Trappist’s commitment to silence is a monastic value which assures solitude in community. It fosters mindfulness of God and fraternal communion. It opens the mind to the inspirations of the Holy Spirit and favours attentiveness of the heart and solitary prayer to God. Early monastic communities evolved [[Monastic sign languages|simple hand signing]] for essential communications. Spoken conversations between monks are permitted, but limited according to the norms established by the community and approved by the Order.
{{quote|"Silence is the mystery of the world to come. Speech is the organ of this present world. More than all things love silence: it brings you a fruit that the tongue cannot describe. In the beginning we have to force ourselves to be silent. But then from our very silence is born something that draws us into deeper silence. May God give you an experience of this 'something' that is born of silence. If you practice this, inexpressible light will dawn upon you."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.virtualmuseum.ca/Exhibitions/Trappist/english/ideas/silence.html |work=A Day in the Life of a Trappist Monk |title=Silence |publisher=Virtualmuseum.ca |date= |accessdate=2012-01-25}}</ref>|sign=Issac of Ninive|http://www.virtualmuseum.ca/Exhibitions/Trappist/english/ideas/silence.html}}
===Protestantism=== [[Baptist]] pastor and evangelist [[Frederick Brotherton Meyer]] (1847–1929), a member of the [[Higher Life movement]], developed a strong commitment to silence, which he saw as one of the ways to gain access to God's guidance on all matters. {{quote|"We must be still before God. The life around us, in this age, is pre eminently one of rush and effort. It is the age of the express train and electric telegraph. Years are crowded into months, and weeks into days. This feverish haste threatens the religious life. The stream has already entered our churches, and stirred their quiet pools. Meetings crowd on meetings. The same energetic souls are found at them all, and engaged in many good works beside. But we must beware that we do not substitute the active for the contemplative, the valley for the mountain top. (...) We must make time to be alone with God. The closet and the shut door are indispensable.(...) Be still, and know that God is within thee and around! In the hush of the soul the unseen becomes visible, and the eternal real. (...) Let no day pass without its season of silent waiting before God."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ccel.org/m/meyer/guidance/guidance.htm |work=The Secret of Guidance |title=Silence |publisher=Fleming H. Revell company |year=1896 |accessdate=2014-03-25}}</ref>|sign=FB Meyer, The Secret of Guidance|http://www.ccel.org/m/meyer/guidance/guidance.htm}}
FB Meyer exerted a deep influence on [[Frank Buchman]] (1878–1961), originally a Protestant evangelist who founded the Oxford Group (known as Moral Re-Armament from 1938 until 2001, and as [[Initiatives of Change]] since then). Foundational to Buchman's spirituality was the practice of a daily "quiet time" during which, he claimed, anyone could search for, and receive, divine guidance on every aspect of their life. Dr Karl Wick, editor of the Swiss Catholic daily ''Vaterland'', wrote that Buchman had "brought silence out of the monastery into the home, the marketplace and the board room."<ref>Article in Silva, 25 March 1962, quoted by Garth Lean, Frank Buchman, A Life, published by Collins, 1985, p.532, {{ISBN|978-0006272403}}, [http://www.frankbuchman.info/]</ref> Buchman, in turn, taught thousands to "listen and obey", finding amazing resonance with non-Christian as well as Christian religions.<ref>See a panorama of Buchman's work on [[Initiatives of Change]] website [http://www.iofc.org/history]</ref>
==Buddhist tradition== [[Buddhist meditation]] techniques make use of ''[[vipassana]]'' and ''[[samatha]]'' techniques in their meditation practice. One of the central categories of Buddhist thought is ''[[sunyata]]'', which can be characterized as the silence of ontological Being. Neither the [[Bodhisattva vows]] of Mahayana Buddhism nor Theravada typically involve any vows of silence. Vowed religious practitioners do not typically practice silence pursuant to their vows, but rather as a local or "denominational" rule of monastic life.
===Zen practice of silence=== The Zen monastery is called the ''zen-dō'', and a primary practice is sitting meditation called ''[[zazen]]''. Zazen is practiced either in silence, or by chanting. Apart from sitting practice, silence is frequently customary during simple vegetarian rice-gruel meals.<ref name="adhood">{{cite web|url=http://zendo.co.tv |title=adhood |publisher=Zendo.co.tv |date= |accessdate=2012-01-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130619213851/http://zendo.co.tv/ |archivedate=June 19, 2013 }}</ref> Codified hand and arm gestures are used to communicate.<ref name="adhood"/> Silence is generally preceded by a recitation of the [[Heart sutra]] and the [[five meditations]].<ref name="adhood"/>
=== Depiction of silence in parable=== Various stories or parables depict silence in meditation and action, in both vowed and lay practice.
:Three monks who had taken vows of silence were permitted an annual reprieve during which one monk was permitted to speak at the end of each year of silence. At the end of the first year, the first monk was allowed his opportunity to speak, whereupon he said "The soup is too hot." Another year elapsed, and it was the next monk's turn. The monks turned their attention to him, whereupon he said "The soup is too cold." Another year elapsed; it was the third monk's turn. The assembled monks turned to him, whereupon he said "The soup is neither too cold nor too hot. However, it is too salty." By the fourth year, the Abbess had posted a notice that it would be she who would speak at the end of that year. The assembled monks were particularly alert to hear the esteemed Abbess give her speech. One could hear the sound of a butterfly's wings in the silence which enveloped the hall. Whereupon the Abess said "There will be no more of this quibbling about the soup." Thus have I heard.<ref>Wisdom from Mom: A American Dharma, D. Virmalakirti, Dharma Bum IMC CCL.3 Press, Austin, 2011</ref>
:Four monks decided to meditate silently without speaking for two weeks. By nightfall on the first day, the candle began to flicker and then went out. The first monk said, "Oh, no! The candle is out." The second monk said, "Aren't we not supposed to talk?" The third monk said, "Why must you two break the silence?" The fourth monk laughed and said, "Ha! I'm the only one who didn't speak."<ref name="detoxifynow1">{{cite web|url=http://www.detoxifynow.com/zen_parables.html |title=Sufi and Zen parables |publisher=Detoxifynow.com |date= |accessdate=2011-06-07}}</ref>
==Silence practice in Judaism== Judaism has a tradition of silence in sacred space and in sacred structures. Although technically not classified as monasteries, synagogues, yeshivas, and ''beit midrash'' (house of study) are the models, along with the [[Tanakh]] (Bible), upon which the monastic silence tradition are built.<ref>{{cite web|first=Amy |last=Hirshberg Lederman|title= Finding meaning in the sound of silence|work= Arizona Jewish Post|date= 23 December 2010 |url=http://azjewishpost.com/2010/finding-meaning-in-the-sound-of-silence}}</ref>
Rabbi Shmuel Afek starts [[minyan]] with five minutes of silence during which each person can engage in his or her own personal preparation for [[tefillah]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.heschel.org/page.cfm?p=266 |title=Abraham Joshua Heschel School: Tefillah |publisher=Heschel.org |date= |accessdate=2012-01-25}}</ref> [[Isadore Twersky]] states in Introduction to the Code of Maimonides: "One must be attuned to the silences".<ref>Isadore Twersky, Introduction to the Code of Maimonides (Mishneh Torah) (New Haven and London: Yale University Press, 1980), p. xvi.</ref>
==Merton: bridging contemplative traditions== [[File:Thanksgiving chapel interior.jpg|thumb|Thanks-Giving Square chapel interior in Dallas, Texas]]
One of the leading exponents of monastic [[contemplative|contemplative awareness]] is [[Thomas Merton]].
===From Thoughts in Solitude (1956)=== According to Merton, silence represents a form of transcending [[koan|paradoxes]] such as he may have encountered in [[zazen]] training.
{{quote|"Contradictions have always existed in the soul of [individuals]. But it is only when we prefer analysis to silence that they become a constant and insoluble problem. We are not meant to resolve all contradictions but to live with them and rise above them and see them in the light of exterior and objective values which make them trivial by comparison."|Thomas Merton|Thoughts in Solitude{{Page needed|date=January 2012}}}}
=== The Asian Journal=== {{quote|"I am able to approach the Buddhas barefoot and undisturbed, my feet in wet grass, wet sand. Then the silence of the extraordinary faces. The great smiles. Huge and yet subtle. Filled with every possibility, questioning nothing, knowing everything, rejecting nothing, the peace not of emotional resignation but of Madhyamika, of sunyata, that has seen through every question without trying to discredit anyone or anything — without refutation — without establishing some other argument. For the doctrinaire, the mind that needs well-established positions, such peace, such silence, can be frightening."|Thomas Merton|The Asian Journal{{Page needed|date=January 2012}}}}
===Monastic life=== {{quote|"The chief function of monastic silence is then to preserve that ''memoria Dei'' which is much more than just 'memory'. It is a total consciousness and awareness of God which is impossible without silence, recollection, solitude and a certain withdrawal."|Thomas Merton|Monastic Life{{Page needed|date=January 2012}}}}
=== Contemplative silence as protest === In addition to being a major figure in the field of contemplative studies, Merton expressed awareness of social issues conscience.
{{quote|"I make monastic silence a protest against the lies of politicians, propagandists and agitators..."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goodhealth.com/articles/2009/09/23/monastic_silence_being_instead_of_doing |title=Monastic Silence: Being instead of Doing - Good Health by Seton |publisher=Goodhealth.com |date=2009-09-23 |accessdate=2011-06-07}}</ref> |Thomas Merton|In My Own Words}}
==East-West concurrence on role of silent practice== Monastic silence is a category of practice which unites faiths<ref>{{cite journal|jstor=1390538 | pages=187–190|title=Word and Silence in Buddhist and Christian Traditions|first1=Donald|last1=Mitchell|volume=19|date=1999|journal=Buddhist-Christian Studies}}</ref> and contributes a perennial topic of convergence between eastern and western traditions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ewtn.com/library/theology/cathbudd.htm |title=Second Buddhist-Christian Colloquium |publisher=Ewtn.com |date= |accessdate=2011-06-07}}</ref> [[Thomas Keating|Father Thomas Keating]] is the founder of Contemplative Outreach and former abbot of St. Benedict's Monastery in Snowmass, Colorado.<ref name="contout">{{cite web|url=http://www.contemplativeoutreach.org/site/PageServer?pagename=about_people_keating |title=Father Thomas Keating |publisher=Contemplative Outreach |date=2010-09-22 |accessdate=2011-06-07}}</ref> He states that "as in Buddhism, Christianity has several contemplative methods. The methods of contemplative prayer are expressed in two traditions: centering prayer, which we represent, and Christian Meditation, designed by John Main, which is now spreading rapidly throughout the world under the charismatic leadership of Father Lawrence Freeman."{{cite quote|date=January 2012}}
Keating's approach is more directly influenced by his collaboration with Buddhists from various traditions, whereas Main is influenced by his travels among Indian Hindus.<ref name="contout" /> Keating states that one "progresses eventually to Christ nature or Buddha nature"<ref name="Monastic Dialogue">{{cite web|author=Monastic Dialogue |url=http://www.monasticdialog.com/a.php?id=57 |title=Monastic Interreligious Dialogue | Fifth Buddhist-Christian Meditation Conference at Naropa |publisher=Monasticdialog.com |date= |accessdate=2011-06-07}}</ref> Keating distinguishes his contemplative method from that of John Main, another teacher of Christian mindfulness, but states an affinity for "interior silence". "The John Main approach is a little different than ours, but both go in the same direction: moving beyond dependence on concepts and words to a direct encounter with God on the level of faith and interior silence."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.livingrosaries.org |accessdate=January 7, 2014 |title=Rosaries for the Contemplative Dimension of Prayer|deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130522081431/http://www.livingrosaries.org/ |archivedate=May 22, 2013 }}</ref>
Fr. James Conner, OCSO wrote about the Fifth Christian–Buddhist Contemplative Conference held at the Naropa Institute in which ordained practitioners from Zen, Vajrayana, and Catholic monastic lineages conducted meditation and discussion. According to Conner, wordless prayer is designed to transcend rational processes to allow perception of an exalted state. "Zen says that Buddha-nature begins where the rational level ends. The same is taught in Christianity. One is to practice thoughtless, wordless prayer and thus perceive the divine presence."<ref name="Monastic Dialogue"/>
===Silence motif injected into cross-cultural adaptation=== Silence is interjected into this Christian parable in some circles.{{By whom|date=January 2012}}
:One of master Gasan's monks visited the university in Tokyo. When he returned, he asked the master if he had ever read the Christian Bible. "No," Gasan replied, "Please read some of it to me." The monk opened the Bible to the Sermon on the Mount in St. Matthew, and began reading. After reading Christ's words about the lilies in the field, he paused. Master Gasan was silent for a long time.<ref name="detoxifynow1"/> "Yes," he finally said, "Whoever uttered these words is an enlightened being. What you have read to me is the essence of everything I have been trying to teach you here!"
The original rendering of this syncope or parable from the Gospel of Luke does not incorporate silence. The adaptation into Zen tradition could have omitted the role of silence. This particular use of silence is neither monastic nor vowed, but the dialogue may well have taken place in a monastery rather than a university.{{Synthesis-inline|date=January 2012}}
Buddhism and Christianity are not the only traditions enunciating the virtues of quietism. The [[Tao Te Ching]] enunciates a view of the supreme value of doing absolutely nothing, in a profound metaphysical sense. This is called [[wu wei]] and is consistent with the concept of [[sunyata]] more fully elaborated in Buddhism.{{Synthesis-inline|date=January 2012}} According to the Tao Te Ching, silence is merely the application of this concept to the tongue in addition to hands and feet.{{Citation needed|date=January 2012}}
==Application of monastic silence practice outside of religious context==
The spiritual practice of silence has been extended into the healthcare setting under the rubric of Mind-Body healing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goodhealth.com/articles/2009/09/23/monastic_silence_being_instead_of_doing |title=Monastic Silence: Being instead of Doing |last=Speier |first=Patricia |publisher=Goodhealth.com |date=2009-09-23 |accessdate=2012-01-25}}</ref> Dr. Jack Engler of the Theravada tradition of Buddhism is Director of the Schiff Psychiatric Center at Harvard University and participates in Christian–Buddhist dialogue. Dr Engller lived as a novice at the Abbey of Gethsemane, which is affiliated with Merton, and studied Buddhist meditation practices in Burma and India.<ref name="Monastic Dialogue"/>

She has a younger sister named [[Rimururu]] and an aggressive darker side alter-ego known as '''Rera'''. As one of SNK's popular mascot characters, Nakoruru has also appeared in many other games and other media. ==Appearances== ===''Samurai Shodown'' games=== Nakoruru is featured as a player character in most game entries in the ''[[Samurai Shodown]]'' series, including ''[[Samurai Shodown (video game)|Samurai Shodown]]'', ''[[Shinsetsu Samurai Spirits Bushidō Retsuden]]'' (a role-playing game), ''[[Samurai Shodown II]]'', ''[[Samurai Shodown III]]'' (where she also makes background appearance in Rimururu's stage), ''[[Samurai Shodown IV]]'', ''[[Samurai Shodown V]]'', ''[[Samurai Shodown V Special]]'', ''[[Samurai Shodown VI]]'', ''[[Samurai Shodown!]]'', ''[[Samurai Shodown 64]]'', ''[[Samurai Shodown! 2]]'', ''[[Samurai Shodown 64: Warriors Rage]]'', and ''[[Samurai Shodown: Edge of Destiny]]'', as well as in mobile spin-off titles such as an endless runner ''Samurai Shodown Slash,''{{cite web|url=http://www.siliconera.com/2014/09/29/samurai-shodown-slash-turns-snks-fighting-game-series-runner/ |title=Samurai Shodown Slash Turns The SNK's Fighting Game Series Into A Runner |publisher=Siliconera |date=2014-09-29 |accessdate=2015-10-01}} an action game ''Samurai: Rougetsuki Densetsu,''{{Cite web|url=http://www.appbank.net/2018/05/01/iphone-application/1540978.php|title=『サムライスピリッツ』新作は和風アクション。佐倉綾音、福山潤など人気声優を起用【侍魂：朧月伝説】|last=|first=|date=|website=AppBank – iPhone, スマホのたのしみを見つけよう|language=ja|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-29}} and a rising simulation ''Maid by Iroha''. Her costume's design was based on Ainu clothing and she was supposed to mix a concept of a "petite girl with a lovely appearance and personality" with an "innovative" character performance of commanding a hawk companion in battle.{{cite web|url=http://neogeomuseum.snkplaymore.co.jp/whats/ |title=What'S "Neogeo"? | Neogeo Museum |publisher=Neogeomuseum.snkplaymore.co.jp |date= |accessdate=2015-10-06|language=Japanese}} Although Nakoruru was not directly modeled after any particular existing character, Hilda from ''[[The Great Adventure of Horus, Prince of the Sun]]'' and Kamui from ''[[The Dagger of Kamui]]'' helped her conception process. The girl that appears during Nakoruru's entrances in ''Capcom vs. SNK'' is one of her childhood friends introduced in ''Nakoruru: Ano Hito kara no Okurimono'', Manari.{{cite web|url=http://www.hardcoregaming101.net/samuraishodown/samuraishodown8.htm |title=Samurai Shodown |publisher=Hardcore Gaming 101 |date= |accessdate=2015-10-01}} Nakoruru was notably the first fighting game character brought back to life following her demise{{cite web|url=http://www.1up.com/do/blogEntry?bId=9116190 |title=Retronauts: 1UP's Classic Gaming Blog : Back to Life |publisher=1up.com |date= |accessdate=2015-10-07}} and one of the first who used a sidekick character in gameplay. Nakoruru is 153 cm tall.{{cite web|url=http://www.snkplaymore.co.jp/us/games/kof-xiv/characters/nakoruru.php |title=THE KING OF FIGHTERS XIV | PlayStation®4 |publisher=Snk Playmore |date= |accessdate=2016-08-29}} An alternate, [[palette swap]] version of her with tanned skin and different colors of hair and eyes is the '''Bust Nakoruru''' (''Rasetsu Nakoruru'') or '''EX Nakoruru,''' a recurring [[Easter egg (media)|Easter egg]] type character that eventually evolved into Rera. Popularly known as {{nihongo|'''Purple Nakoruru'''|紫ナコルル|Murasaki Nakoruru}}, she is a crueler and cockier version of Nakoruru, more violent about fulfilling her mission to protect nature, and her companion is Shikuru the wolf. In [[fan service]] oriented fighting game ''SNK Heroines: Tag Team Frenzy'', Nakoruru appears as default in a "sexy vampire" costume with a bat as her animal,{{Cite web|url=https://www.gamer.ne.jp/news/201801290015/|title=ヴァンパイアコスチュームのナコルルが登場！PS4/Nintendo Switch「SNKヒロインズ Tag Team Frenzy」最新トレーラーが公開｜Gamer|last=Gamer|website=www.gamer.ne.jp|language=ja|access-date=2018-05-15}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.techtimes.com/articles/219905/20180130/samurai-shodown-s-nakoruru-makes-appeareance-in-snk-heroines-tag-team-frenzy-trailer.htm|title=Samurai Shodown’s Nakoruru Makes Appeareance In SNK Heroines: Tag Team Frenzy Trailer|last=Cannon|first=William|date=2018-01-30|work=Tech Times|access-date=2018-05-15|language=en}} while in ''The King of Fighters XIV'' she can be dressed up in a modern schoolgirl uniform.{{Cite web|url=https://www.famitsu.com/news/201701/27125686.html|title=『ザ・キング・オブ・ファイターズ XIV』ナコルルの女子校制服とシュンエイの修行道着が配信開始 - ファミ通.com|website=ファミ通.com|language=ja|access-date=2018-05-15}} To compensate for Nakoruru's short weapon range, players must rely on her speed to punish their opponents' mistakes. Nakoruru's strengths lie in her air supremacy (including aerial throws) and ability to jump around the sides of the screen.''MAXIMUM The Video Game Magazine'' issue 3 (January 1996) pages 50-52. She can also recover from her moves a little quicker than other characters, making it easier for her to hit-and-run during fights. To balance her out with the rest of the cast, her attack strength is slightly weaker than most fighters. Her move set usually incorporates slightly longer ranged attacks that project her or her animal companions to her foes so her attack range is not limited to her sword. Since ''Samurai Shodown II'', she can also reflect projectiles with the move "Kamui Ryusei".''Electronic Gaming Monthly'' issue 66 (January 1995) page 242. Mamahaha can be used by the player to attack opponents in a diagonal aerial attack, acting as Nakoruru's projectile and anti-air defense. The player may also command Nakoruru to use him as a mount for a limited time. Whilst she is in the air, players can command the pair to hover higher, drop, or use Nakoruru to attack foes; she may do so normally from Mamahaha's height or players may choose to drop her in a swirl attacking motion or use a diagonal nosedive attack. Her moves' names are written in the [[Ainu language]]. Prior to ''Samurai Shodown V Special'', Nakoruru and Rimururu have been the series' two characters notable for being immune to the [[Fatality (Mortal Kombat)|Fatality]]-like bloody killing moves.{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/stream/Tips_Tricks_Volume_IV_Issue_3_1997-03_LFP_US/Tips__Tricks_Volume_IV_Issue_3_1997-03_LFP_US#page/n13/mode/2up/ |title=Tips & Tricks - Volume IV Issue 3 (1997-03)(LFP)(US) |publisher=Archive.org |date= |accessdate=2015-10-06}}{{cite web|author=小暮ひさのり |url=http://www.kotaku.jp/2013/07/samurai_spirits.html |title=おこなの？ 激おこなの？ あの『真SAMURAI SPIRITS』がスマホに移植！ ｜ コタク・ジャパン |publisher=Kotaku.jp |date= |accessdate=2015-10-06|language=Japanese}}{{Cite news|url=https://game.watch.impress.co.jp/docs/review/1119507.html|title=【名作発掘】「アケアカNEOGEO サムライスピリッツ 天草降臨」レビュー シリーズ屈指の異色作「サムスピ 天草降臨」を怒り爆発でプレイ!! アケアカNEOGEO サムライスピリッツ 天草降臨|last=|first=|date=2018-04-27|work=GAME Watch|access-date=2018-07-29|language=ja-JP}} In ''Samurai Shodown: Edge of Destiny'', Mamahaha does not appear in fights except in special moves.{{cite web|url=http://worthplaying.com/article/2010/4/24/reviews/73862/ |title=Xbox 360 Review - 'Samurai Shodown Sen' |publisher=Worthplaying |date= |accessdate=2015-10-06}} The presence of monkeys in Nakoruru's stage in the original ''Samurai Shodown'' was a mistake of the background designer Tomoki Fukui which confused many fans as there are no monkeys on Hokkaido.{{Cite news|url=https://www.polygon.com/2017/4/10/15223966/the-making-of-samurai-shodown|title=The making of Samurai Shodown|work=Polygon|access-date=2018-05-15}} ==Rera== [[File:Rera SS.png|thumb|Rera with Shikuru the wolf in ''[[Samurai Shodown VI]]''|alt=]] {{nihongo|Rera|レラ|Rera}} (meaning "Wind" in Ainu) is a player character introduced in 2003. Her mannerism was based on Nakoruru's "Bust" form, being a violent and haughty ego of hers.{{cite web | author=SNK Playmore | title=Samurai Spirits V Creators Commentary | url=http://www.samurai-zero.jp/coment.html | work=Web Archive from Samurai Shodown V page | accessdate=January 1, 2008 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20031207052700/http://www.samurai-zero.jp/coment.html | archivedate=December 7, 2003 | language=Japanese | deadurl=yes}} The ruthless Nakoruru suppresses this side of herself as Rera sees "eliminating everyone who stands in her way" as a necessity to protect nature. Rera can physically take over Nakoruru, but has only done so when Nakoruru is reluctant to kill her enemies, and even manifest as a separate material entity to protect her host. Rera eventually merges back with Nakoruru after she realizes that fighting does not solve everything and peaceful solutions can be made.{{cite web|url=http://www.vgmuseum.com/end/neogeo/a/sszrer.htm |title=Ending for Samurai Spirits Zero-Rera(Neo Geo) |publisher=Vgmuseum.com |date= |accessdate=2015-10-01}} Rera is playable in ''Samurai Shodown V'' and ''VI''. Similar to Nakoruru's "Bust" form in ''Samurai Shodown III'' and ''IV'', she too wields a kodachi and fights alongside her wolf, Shikuru, which primarily serves as a mount for her mount and is a necessity for several her special moves. Whilst Rera mounts him, the player can run faster and jump longer distances at the sacrifice of a lower height. She also appears in ''Days of Memories'' and in the film ''Nakoruru: Ano Hito kara no Okurimono''. ==Reception and cultural impact== As an iconic{{cite Lyons, Jr. | image = | imagesize = 200px | alt = | caption = Lyons at [[Nambassa]] in 1981 | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth year and age|1930}} | birth_place = [[New York (state)|New York]], United States | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = American, [[Onondaga Nation|Onondaga]] | field = | training = BFA [[Syracuse University]] | movement = | works = | patrons = | influenced by = | influenced = | awards = | elected = | website = }}
'''Oren R. Lyons, Jr.''' (born 1930) is a [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] Faithkeeper of the [[Iroquois#Clans|Turtle Clan]] of the [[Seneca Nation]]s of the [[Iroquois|Iroquois Confederacy]].<ref name=buffalo>[http://www.americanstudies.buffalo.edu/people/faculty/lyons/index.shtml "Department of American Studies Faculty: Oren R. Lyons."] ''University of Buffalo, College of Arts and Sciences.'' (retrieved 26 Aug 2010)</ref> Once a college [[lacrosse]] player, Lyons is now a recognized advocate of [[indigenous people|indigenous]] rights.<ref name=syra>[http://www.syracusehalloffame.com/pages/inductees/1988/oren_lyons.html Oren Lyons, Jr.: Lacrosse.] ''Greater Syracuse Sports Hall of Fame.'' (retrieved 26 Aug 2010)</ref>
==Background, education, and athletic career== Oren Lyons, Jr. was born in 1930 and raised in the culture and practices of the Iroquois on the [[Cattaraugus Reservation|Seneca]] and [[Onondaga Reservation|Onondaga]] [[Indian reservation|reservations]] in [[Upstate New York]].<ref name=syra/>
Lyons served in the [[United States Army]]. He received an athletic scholarships to [[Syracuse University]], where he was awarded the Orange Key for his academic and athletic accomplishments.<ref>Hope and Young 164-5</ref> He graduated from the College of Fine Arts in 1958. A lifelong [[lacrosse]] player,<ref>Hope and Young 164</ref> Oren was an [[All-American]] at Syracuse, where the [[Syracuse Orange men's lacrosse]] went undefeated during his graduating year.<ref name=syra/> After graduation, Lyons played for several teams, including the New York Lacrosse Club (1959–1965), the New Jersey Lacrosse Club (1966–1970), and the Onondaga Athletic Club (1970–1972).<ref name=syra/>
Upon leaving Syracuse, Lyons pursued a career in commercial art in [[New York City]], becoming the art and planning director of Norcross Greeting Cards.<ref name=w165>Hope and Young 165</ref> Outside of work, Lyons exhibited his own paintings during this time{{Citation needed|date=March 2009}}. In 1970, Lyons returned to [[Onondaga County, New York|Onondaga]] to be closer to his cultural heritage{{Original research inline|date=March 2009}}. In recognition of his contributions over many years as a teacher of undergraduate and graduate students in the University at Buffalo, Dr. Lyons is listed as SUNY Distinguished Service Professor and Professor Emeritus of American Studies in the UB College of Arts and Sciences.<ref name=buffalo/>
==Activism== In the 1960s, Lyons joined the [[Red Power movement]] and joined the Unity Caravan, which traveled through [[Indian Country]] to foster dialogue about traditional tribal values. In 1972, he was a leader in the [[Trail of Broken Treaties]], a caravan to Washington DC to convince the [[Bureau of Indian Affairs]] to honor its treaties with [[Native American tribes]].<ref name=w165/>
In 1977, Lyons helped create the Traditional Circle of Indian Elders and Youth at a meeting in [[Montana]]. Since then, the Circle has gathered annually at a different site in [[Indian reservation|Indian country]].<ref>[http://www.twocircles.org/aboutaii.html] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060221221648/http://www.twocircles.org/aboutaii.html |date=February 21, 2006 }}</ref> In 1977, he also was part of the [[Haudenosaunee]] delegation to the first [[World Conference on Racism]].<ref name=w165/>
"At first, I wanted to defend the Iroquois. Then my sights broadened to embrace other Indians. Then I saw this had to include defending indigenous peoples all over the world," Lyons said.<ref name=w165/>
In 1981, he traveled with [[Stephen Gaskin]] and [[Ina May Gaskin]] to [[New Zealand]] to attend festival at [[Nambassa]], where he delivered a number of lectures and workshops. At Nambassa he coordinated with [[Māori people|Indigenous Maori]] [[land rights|land rights activists]] on questions of [[indigenous peoples]] sharing his Native American experiences <ref>http://nlnzcat.natlib.govt.nz/vprimo/getHoldings?bibId=91409&pds_handle=</ref>
For over fourteen years he has taken part in the meetings in [[Geneva]] of Indigenous Peoples of the Human Rights Commission of the [[United Nations]], and helped to establish the [[Working Group on Indigenous Populations]] in 1982{{Citation needed|date=March 2009}}. He serves on the Executive Committee of the Global Forum of Spiritual and Parliamentary Leaders on Human Survival, and is a principal figure in the Traditional Circle of Indian Elders. He was a negotiator between the governments of [[Canada]], [[Quebec]], [[New York State]] and the Mohawks in the [[Oka crisis]] during the summer of 1990.{{Citation needed|date=March 2009}}
Lyons appeared on a one-hour [[Documentary film|documentary]] ''Faithkeeper'', produced and hosted by [[Bill Moyers]]<ref>Brussat, Frederic and Mary Ann. [http://www.spiritualityandpractice.com/films/films.php?id=6300 "Film Review: The Faithkeeper."] ''Spirituality and Practice.'' (retrieved 26 Aug 2010)</ref> and broadcast on [[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]], July 3, 1991. He appeared in Leonardo DiCaprio's documentary "[[The 11th Hour (2007 film)|The 11th Hour]]" in 2007.
In 1992 he addressed the General Assembly of the United Nations where he opened the International Year of the World's Indigenous Peoples <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.11thhouraction.com/ideasandexperts/orenlyons |title=Oren Lyons - Attraction |publisher=11thhouraction.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-02}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ratical.org/many_worlds/6Nations/OLatUNin92.html | title=Oren Lyons Opening Statement, "The Year of the Indigenous Peoples" (1993), in the UN General Assembly Auditorium |publisher=Ratical.org |date=1992-12-10 |accessdate=2011-11-02}}</ref>
==Recognition== Lyons has been awarded an [[Honorary degree|honorary]] [[Doctor of Laws#United States|Doctor of Laws]] degree from Syracuse University.<ref>http://archives.syr.edu/awards/honorary_1.html</ref>
He has been the recipient of the [[Ellis Island Medal of Honor]], the [[National Audubon Society]]'s Audubon Medal, the [[Earth Day]] International Award of the United Nations, and the Elder and Wiser Award of the [[Rosa Parks Institute]] for Human Rights.<ref name=buffalo/> Lyons serves on the board of the [[Harvard Project on American Indian Economic Development]] and is board chairman of Honoring Contributions in the Governance of American Indian Nations.<ref name=buffalo/>
Lyons is also remembered for his time as a lacrosse player. He is Honorary Chairman of the [[Iroquois Nationals]].<ref name=syra/> In 1989 he was named Man of the Year in Lacrosse by the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]].<ref name=syra/>
His legendary performance as goalkeeper for Syracuse University, with Jim Brown on the undefeated 1957 national champion team, led to the induction of Oren R. Lyons, Jr. into the [[Lacrosse Museum and National Hall of Fame|National Lacrosse Hall of Fame]] in 1992.<ref>[http://apps.uslacrosse.org/museum/halloffame/view_profile.php?prof_id=136]. See also Gordon White, "Jim Brown's Best Sport Was Lacrosse," THE PILOT (www.thepilot.com), May 23, 2010.</ref>
==Published works== Lyons has authored numerous books. He has also illustrated children's books in collaboration with [[Virginia Driving Hawk Sneve]] ([[Brulé Lakota]]). He is the publisher of ''Daybreak Magazine''.<ref name=buffalo/>

Holiday House, 1995. {{ISBN|978-0-8234-0212-0}}. *Sneve, Virginia Driving Hawk, author, and Oren Lyons, illustrator. ''When Thunders Spoke.'' ASIN B003BGS43K. *Sneve, Virginia Driving Hawk, author, and Oren Lyons, illustrator. ''Jimmy Yellow Hawk.'' Holiday House, 1972. The '''Parahiya''' are a [[Hindu]] [[Caste system in India|caste]] found in the state of [[Uttar Pradesh]] in India.
==Origin== The name ''Parahiya'' is said to mean in the [[Gondi language]] ''the burners of the forest'' because they practice [[slash and burn]] agriculture. According to other traditions, the name is corruption of the word ''Paharia'', which in [[Hindi]] means a hill dweller. They are one of a number of tribal communities such as the [[Panika]] that occupy the foothills of the [[Vindhya Range|Vindhya]] mountains. The community speak a dialect of Hindi.<ref name="poi">People of India Uttar Pradesh Volume XLII Part Three edited by A Hasan & J C Das page 1120 to 1124 Manohar Publications</ref>
==Present circumstances== The habitat of most of the Parhiya is the hilly, undulating and extremely forested southern part of [[Sonbhadra district]], at the foot of the Vindhya mountains. They are [[endogamy|endogamous]] and divided into a number of [[exogamy|exogamous]] clans known as kuris, of which the main ones are the Bengeha, Bhaloa, Bhania, Bhusan, Gohawa, Gurgur, Monnoor and Sira. Although they are Hindu, they also have a number of their own tribal deities such as Jawalamukhi Devi and Dharti Mata.<ref name="poi" />
The Parahiya depend on the forest for their subsistence. They are small landholding community. Hunting and gathering forest produce is an important source of their income. They collect roots, tubers, fruits, lacs and leaves, which they sell at the local market. They no longer engage in hunting as settled cultivation is now their occupation.<ref name="poi" />
The [[Government of Uttar Pradesh]] had classified them as a [[Scheduled Caste]] but by 2007, they were one of several groups that it had redesignated as [[Scheduled Tribes]].<ref>{{cite journal |title=State At A Glance - Uttar Pradesh |date=July 2007 |journal=Pratiyogita Darpan |volume=2 |issue=13 |page=81|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=7egDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PT72}}</ref> As of 2017, this designation applies only in [[Sonbhadra district]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://tribal.nic.in/WriteReadData/CMS/Documents/201212010356439267578File1068.pdf |title=State wise Scheduled Tribes — Uttar Pradesh |publisher=Ministry of Tribal Affairs, Government of India |accessdate=2017-02-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161123041643/http://tribal.nic.in/WriteReadData/CMS/Documents/201212010356439267578File1068.pdf |archivedate=2016-11-23 |df= }}</ref> as it also did at the time of the [[2011 Census of India]] when the Parahiya Scheduled Caste population in Uttar Pradesh was 2446.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.censusindia.gov.in/2011census/PCA/SC_ST/PCA-A10/SC-0900-PCA-A-10-ddw.xlsx |title= A-10 Individual Scheduled Caste Primary Census Abstract Data and its Appendix - Uttar Pradesh |publisher=Registrar General & Census Commissioner, India |accessdate=2017-02-04}}</ref>

{{About|a 1980 comedy film, also known as ''KGOD''|the 1982 made-for-television drama|Pray TV (1982 film)|the actual radio station with these [[call letters]]|KGOD-LP}} {{Infobox film | name = Pray TV | image = Pray TV.jpg | image_size = | caption = DVD cover | director = [[Rick Friedberg]] | producer = {{ubl|Rick Friedberg|[[Tina Stern]]}} | writer = {{ubl|[[Nick Castle]]|[[Dick Chudnow]]|Rick Friedberg}} || starring = {{ubl|[[Dabney Coleman]]|Paul Cooper}} | music = [[George S. Clinton]] | cinematography = | editing = | studio = [[ABC Circle Films]] | distributor = [[Filmways Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|1980}} | runtime = | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = }} '''''Pray TV''''' (also known as '''''KGOD''''')<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=7dFHAAAAIBAJ&sjid=i38MAAAAIBAJ&pg=1958,1207809&dq=pray-tv+coleman&hl=en|author=[[Associated Press]] (AP)|title=Being Nice Didn't Get Coleman Where He Is|date=June 5, 1983|accessdate=November 14, 2011|work=[[The Victoria Advocate]]|page=9TV}}</ref> is a 1980 comedy film spoofing [[televangelism]].
==Plot== Failing [[UHF]] TV station KRUD, Channel 17, is "reborn" as Christian television station KGOD. The new format is a big success but attracts an incompatible mix of fringe ministries and broadcasters wanting time on the station. A series of humorous vignettes show the different religious shows the station broadcasts: a [[faith healer]], a radical [[black nationalist]] preacher, a preacher with a drive-in church, a Christian [[game show]], etc.
The film is very similar in both plot and style to the 1989 film ''[[UHF (film)|UHF]]''.<ref>[http://www.reelfilm.com/mgmcult.htm David Nusair, "Six Comedy Cult Classics from MGM", reelfilm.com, November 2005]</ref><ref>[http://www.dvdtalk.com/reviews/18817/pray-tv/ Scott Weinberg, "Pray TV", DVD Talk, November 15, 2005]</ref>
==Production== ''Pray TV'' stars [[Dabney Coleman]], Paul Cooper, Rosemary Alexander, and [[Lewis Arquette]], with cameos by [[Paul Reubens]] and the band [[Devo]] (who play a [[Christian rock]] band named "Dove"). It was directed by Rick Friedberg.
==Release== ''Pray TV'' was picked up by [[Filmways Pictures]] in 1980 (under its original name, ''KGOD'').<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iasqAQAAIAAJ&q=KGOD&dq=KGOD&hl=en|title=Acquisitions (p. 26); No title available (p. 41)|year=1980|accessdate=November 14, 2011|work=Film Bulletin|publisher=Wax Publications|volume=49|page=26, 41}}</ref> The film premiered on television instead of theatrically,<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2RacqQu0B3IC&q=KGOD+-+%22Pray+TV%22&dq=KGOD+-+%22Pray+TV%22&hl=en|title=VideoHound's Golden Movie Retriever 1997|chapter=Pray TV|page=xiii|isbn=0-7876-0780-0|year=1996|accessdate=November 14, 2011|publisher=Visible Ink Press/[[Gale (publisher)|Gale/Cengage Learning]]}}</ref> and aired on [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]] in 1983 under its present title.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=y8dFAAAAIBAJ&sjid=4-cMAAAAIBAJ&dq=pray-tv%20coleman&pg=5761%2C2318983 |title=Television movies|date=March 18, 1983|accessdate=November 14, 2011|work=[[The Telegraph-Herald]]|page=19 (Entertainment Section)}}</ref>

[[File:Ewige Profess.jpg|thumb|Perpetual vows and [[consecration of virgins]] in the Benedictine priory of Marienrode in Germany, 2006]] {{Redirect-distinguish|Votary|Notary}} '''Religious vows''' are the public [[vows]] made by the members of religious communities pertaining to their conduct, practices, and views.
In the [[Buddhism|Buddhist]] tradition, in particular within the [[Mahayana]] and [[Vajrayana]] tradition, many different kinds of religious vows are taken by the lay community as well as by the monastic community, as they progress along the path of their practice. In the monastic tradition of all schools of Buddhism the [[Vinaya]] expounds the vows of the fully ordained Nuns and Monks.
In the [[Christianity|Christian]] tradition, such public vows are made by the religious – [[Cenobium|cenobitic]] and [[Hermit|eremitic]] – of the Catholic Church, Anglican Communion, and Eastern Orthodox Churches, whereby they confirm their public profession of the [[Evangelical Counsels]] of poverty, chastity, and obedience or [[Rule of St Benedict|Benedictine]] equivalent. The vows are regarded as the individual's free response to a call by God to follow [[Jesus Christ]] more closely under the action of the [[Holy Spirit]] in a particular form of [[Christian monasticism|religious living]]. A person who lives a religious life according to vows they have made is called a ''votary'' or a ''votarist''. The religious vow, being a public vow, is binding in [[Church law]]. One of its effects is that the person making it ceases to be free to marry. In the Catholic Church, by joining the consecrated life, one does not become a member of the [[Catholic Church hierarchy|hierarchy]] but becomes a member of a state of life which is neither [[Catholic Church hierarchy#The Clergy|clerical]] nor [[Catholic Church hierarchy#Laity|lay]], the consecrated state.<ref>[http://www.intratext.com/IXT/ENG0017/_P1X.HTM 1983 Code of Canon Law, Canon 588]</ref> Nevertheless, the members of the religious orders and those hermits who are in [[Holy Orders]] are members of the [[Catholic Church hierarchy|hierarchy]].<ref>[https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http://uk.geocities.com/deo_auxiliante%40btinternet.com/churchchart.html&date=2009-10-25+04:14:48 Chart showing the place of those making religious vows among the People of God]</ref>
== In the Western Church == Since the 6th century, [[monk]]s and [[nun]]s following the [[Rule of Saint Benedict]] have been making the so-called Benedictine vow at their public [[Profession (religious)#Religious profession|profession]] of obedience (placing oneself under the direction of the abbot/abbess or prior/prioress), stability (committing oneself to a particular monastery), and "conversion of manners" (which includes forgoing private ownership and celibate chastity).<ref>Rule of St Benedict, ch. 58:17.</ref>
During the 12th and 13th centuries [[mendicant orders]] emerged, such as the [[Franciscans]] and [[Dominican Order|Dominicans]], whose vocation emphasizing mobility and flexibility required them to drop the concept of "stability". They therefore [[Profession (religious)#Religious profession|profess]] ''chastity, poverty and obedience'', like the members of many other orders and religious congregations founded subsequently. The public [[Profession (religious)#Religious profession|profession]] of these so-called [[Evangelical counsels]] (or [[counsels of perfection]]), confirmed by vow or other sacred bond, are now a requirement according to modern Church Law.<ref>In the Roman Catholic Church, see canons 573, 603 and 654 of the Code of Canon Law 1983; only the Benedictines continue to make the equivalent Benedictine vow.</ref>
The "clerks regular" of the 16th century and after, such as the [[Jesuits]] and [[Redemptorists]], followed this same general format, though some added a "[[fourth vow]]", indicating some special apostolate or attitude within the order. Fully professed Jesuits (known as "the professed of the fourth vow" within the order), take a vow of particular obedience to the [[Pope]] to undertake any mission laid out in their Formula of the Institute. The [[Missionaries of Charity]], founded by [[St. Teresa of Calcutta]] centuries later (1940s), are another example of this, in that her sisters take a fourth vow of special service to "the poorest of the poor".
=== In the Catholic Church === {{main|Consecrated life (Catholic Church)}} In the [[Catholic Church]], the vows of members of religious orders and congregations are regulated by canons 654-658 of the [[Canon law (Catholic Church)|Code of Canon Law]]. These are public vows, meaning vows accepted by a superior in the name of the Church,<ref>[http://www.vatican.va/archive/ENG1104/__P4E.HTM Code of Canon Law, canon 1192 §2]</ref> and they are usually of two durations: temporary, and, after a few years, final vows (permanent or "perpetual"). Depending on the order, temporary vows may be renewed a number of times before permission to take final vows is given. There are exceptions: the [[Jesuits]]' first vows are perpetual, for instance, and the [[Sisters of Charity]] take only temporary but renewable vows.
Religious vows are of two varieties: [[simple vows]] and [[solemn vows]]. The highest level of commitment is exemplified by those who have taken their solemn, perpetual vows. There once were significant technical differences between them in [[canon law]]; but these differences were suppressed by the current [[1983 Code of Canon Law|Code of Canon Law]] in 1983, although the nominal distinction is maintained. Only a limited number of religious congregations may invite their members to solemn vows; most religious congregations are only authorized to take simple vows. Even in congregations with solemn vows, some members with perpetual vows may have taken them simply rather than solemnly.
A perpetual vow can be superseded by the Pope, when he decides that a man under perpetual vows should become a Bishop of the Church. In these cases, the ties to the order the new Bishop had, are dissolved as if the Bishop had never been a member; hence, such a person as, e.g., Pope Francis has had no formal ties to his old order for years. However, if the Bishop was a member in good standing, he will be regarded, informally, as "one of us", and he will always be welcome in any of the order's houses.
There are other forms of [[consecrated life]] in the Catholic Church for men and women. They make a public profession of the [[evangelical counsels]] of chastity, poverty, and obedience, confirmed by a vow or other sacred bond, regulated by [[canon law]] but live consecrated lives in the world (i.e. not as members of a [[religious institute]]). Such are the [[secular institute]]s, the [[Hermit#Consecrated diocesan hermits (canon 603)|hermits]] and the [[consecrated virgin]]s (canon 604) These make a public profession of the evangelical counsels by a vow or other sacred bond. Also similar are the [[society of apostolic life|societies of apostolic life]].
==In the Eastern Orthodox Church== {{main|Monasticism#Christian monasticism|Degrees of Eastern Orthodox monasticism}} Although the taking of vows was not a part of the earliest monastic foundations (the wearing of a particular monastic habit is the earliest recorded manifestation of those who had left the world), vows did come to be accepted as a normal part of the [[Tonsure#Christianity|Tonsure]] service in the Christian East. Previously, one would simply find a [[Hesychasm|spiritual father]] and live under his direction. Once one put on the monastic habit, it was understood that one had made a lifetime commitment to God and would remain steadfast in it to the end. Over time, however, the formal Tonsure and taking of vows was adopted to impress upon the monastic the seriousness of the commitment to the ascetic life he or she was adopting.
The vows taken by Orthodox monks are: Chastity, poverty, obedience, and stability. The vows are administered by the [[Hegumen|Abbot]] or [[Hieromonk]] who performs the service. Following a period of instruction and testing as a novice, a monk or nun may be tonsured with the permission of the candidate's spiritual father. There are three degrees of monasticism in the Orthodox Church: The [[Rassophore#Eastern Orthodox monks|Ryassaphore]] (one who wears the [[Cassock#Eastern practice (Orthodox and Eastern-rite Catholic)|Ryassa]] – however, there are no vows at this level – the Stavrophore (one who wears the cross), and the Schema-monk (one who wears the [[Great Schema]]; i.e., the full monastic habit). The one administering the tonsure must be an ordained priest, and must be a monk of at least the rank he is tonsuring the candidate into. However a [[Eastern Orthodox Church#Organization and leadership|Bishop]] (who, in the Orthodox Church, must always be a monk) may tonsure a monk or nun into any degree regardless of his own monastic rank.

{{Infobox TV channel | name = Sangat TV | logofile = Sangat TV logo.png | logosize = 150px | logocaption = Sangat TV logo | launch = 1 September 2010 | owner = Sangat Trust | replaced names = [[JML Direct TV|JML Lifestyle]] | web = [http://sangattelevision.org/ sangattelevision.org] | sat serv 1 = [[Sky (UK and Ireland)|Sky]] | sat chan 1 = Channel 755 | sat serv 2 = [[Astra 2F]] | sat chan 2 = 12522 V 22000 5/6 | online serv 1 = [[Justin.tv]] | online chan 1 = [http://www.justin.tv/sangattelevision Watch live] }} {{Sikhism sidebar}}
'''Sangat Television''' is TV channel, and is a Project of, and wholly owned by Sangat Trust, a Registered UK charity. The station commenced broadcasting on 1 September 2010, as part of a two-week test phase.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://media247.co.uk/bizasia/newsarchive/2010/09/confusion_over.php|title=Confusion over Sikh religious channel launch|publisher=Biz Asia|date=1 September 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101125154845/http://media247.co.uk/bizasia/newsarchive/2010/09/confusion_over.php|archivedate=25 November 2010|df=}}</ref>
==Description== Sangat TV is owned by Sangat Trust, a UK Registered Charity backed by [[gurdwara]]s from the UK and from other individuals. The channel is an open platform for the Sikhs [[Sangat (term)|sangat]] to express their views independently. Programming includes educational material on the [[Sikh gurus]] and [[Guru Granth Sahib]]. The channel is now broadcast on Sky channel 755.
==West Midlands riots== Sangat TV came into prominence during the [[2011 England riots|West Midlands riots of August 2011]].<ref name="West Midlands riots">{{cite news |title=West Midlands riots: Sangat TV gets to the heart of the action |author=Huma Qureshi |author2=Mark Sweney |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/aug/10/west-midlands-riots-sangat-tv |publisher=The Guardian |date=10 August 2011 |accessdate=10 August 2011}}</ref> The presenter Upinder Randhawa notably broadcast live from the streets of Birmingham from the first day of rioting in the area, Monday 8 August 2011,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://media247.co.uk/bizasia/newsarchive/2011/08/sangat_tv_switc.php|title=Sangat TV switches to Birmingham riots coverage|publisher=Biz Asia|date=9 August 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120408214116/http://media247.co.uk/bizasia/newsarchive/2011/08/sangat_tv_switc.php|archivedate=8 April 2012|df=}}</ref><ref>[http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/uk-riots-sangat-tv-196099 "UK Riots 2011: Sangat TV Praised for its Heroic Live Coverage"]. ''International Business Times'', August 11, 2011</ref> to provide accurate, live information and broadcasts. Coverage was extended to the surrounding areas such as West Bromwich and Wolverhampton the following night. The channel's coverage was used by [[BBC News (TV channel)|BBC News]], [[ITN]] and [[Sky News]] as well as international stations such as [[CNN]], [[Fox News Channel|Fox News]] and [[NDTV 24x7]] to show what was happening in the area.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://media247.co.uk/bizasia/newsarchive/2011/08/should_asian_me.php|title=Should Asian media follow Sangat TV's coverage?|publisher=Biz Asia|date=10 August 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110910101431/http://media247.co.uk/bizasia/newsarchive/2011/08/should_asian_me.php|archivedate=10 September 2011|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Riots turn Sikh TV channel into global hit |author=Jiten Karia |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/5b2e6596-c4f1-11e0-9c4d-00144feabdc0.html |publisher=Financial Times |date=12 August 2011 |accessdate=14 August 2011}}</ref>
This coverage included sequences of [[Citizen journalism|guerrilla journalism]], most notably footage of the reporting team transporting a police officer in their vehicle in pursuit of looters while live on air.<ref>{{cite news |title=Sangat TV's guerrilla journalism wins fans amid riots |author=Caroline Gall |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-birmingham-14493399 |publisher=BBC News |date=12 August 2011 |accessdate=14 August 2011}}</ref> The popularity of the coverage led to Sangat TV presenter Upinder Randhawa's [[Twitter]] following jumping from 600 users to about 4,000 users in one night,<ref name="West Midlands riots" /> as well as having over 4,000 followers to a fan page on [[Facebook]] called "Upinder Randhawa from Sangat TV is a Legend".<ref>{{cite news |title=UK riots: British sikh TV presenter now a Facebook hero |agency=Indo-Asian News Service |url=http://www.dnaindia.com/world/report_uk-riots-british-sikh-tv-presenter-now-a-facebook-hero_1575243 |publisher=Daily News and Analysis |date=12 August 2011 |accessdate=25 February 2013}}</ref> [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Prime Minister]] [[David Cameron]] hailed Sangat TV's contribution as "an example of a media company's commitment to social responsibility".<ref>{{cite news |title=Live & raw: Sikh TV channel wins kudos for coverage |author=Ashis Ray |url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-08-13/uk/29883975_1_news-channels-exclusive-footage-live-coverage |publisher=Times of India |date=13 August 2011 |accessdate=14 August 2011}}</ref> On 10 August 2011, [[Ofcom]] said it had received one complaint about the previous night's coverage of the riots, in relation to alleged incitement to violence over comments urging people to get out on the streets and protect their property.<ref name="West Midlands riots" />
==Management issues == In 2016, most of the staff of Sangat TV had mostly resigned due to the poor treatment, underpay, where the staff were paid as little as £600 a month for doing a 40 hour a week shift. The channel then has lost most of its programming and it ran as a registered charity with [[Charity Commission for England and Wales|Charity Commission of England and Wales]] with charity number 1139995.
In August 2016, word went round that Sangat TV would be moving its base from [[Edgbaston|Edgbaston, Birmingham]] to [[Southall|Southall, London]] in a bid to get better content and volunteers to run the channel.
==Ofcom / broadcasting issues== Sangat TV was fined £30,000 over a debate in which guests supported an assassination attempt on a former Indian Army general, [[Kuldip Singh Brar]], who led the army attack on [[Akal Takht]] in [[Operation Blue Star]] in June 1984.
In 2015, the [[Ofcom]] [[Broadcasting]] Code was broken when Sangat TV continuously aired a song hailing 'Sukha Jinda', two criminals who had robbed a bank, with justification that it was an advert from [[Dharam Seva Records]]. The complainant considered that the video glorified the actions of two Sikh nationalists [[Harjinder Singh Jinda]] and [[Sukhdev Singh Sukha]] ("Jinda" and "Sukha" respectively). These men, who were members of the [[Khalistan Commando Force]], were hanged in 1992 for the assassination of General [[Arun Shridhar Vaidya|Arun Shridhar Vadiya]], the Chief of the [[Indian Army]] responsible for [[Operation Blue Star|Operation Bluestar]] in 1984. They were also found responsible for the murder of two Indian politicians.
Ofcom upheld a complaint made by Dr Parvinder Singh Garcha. The programme, which aired in September 2014 included a live debate in advance of an election for a new committee to run the [[Gurdwara]] Sri Guru Singh Sabha in Southall, West London. At the end of the debate two videos were shown. The second video also included the claim that money had been stolen from a donation box in the Gurdwara during a period when the Baaj Group was in control. Ofcom noted that the decision to include the second video was made by the presenter during the course of the programme and that Dr Garcha said that he had left the studio before at the end of the debate (i.e. before the video in question was shown). However, in Ofcom's view, it is reasonable to expect that before making such a decision, a broadcaster would be familiar with the content of any material it planned to broadcast. Ofcom considered that the Baaj Group was treated unfairly in this respect in the programme as broadcast.

{{Orphan|date=October 2015}}
'''Seppo Ilmari Salko''' (born 20 April 1941<ref>{{cite book | last = Tauno Väinölä (ed.) | title =Me kaukana ja lähellä. |trans-title = ‘We far and near’ | year =1975 | page =150 | id = Yearbook of the Finnish Missionary Society 1975 | location = Joensuu | publisher = The Finnish Missionary Society | accessdate = | language = fi }}</ref> in [[Oulu]], [[Finland]]<ref name = Esitutkintapoytakirja >Pretrial protocols, interrogation of the plaintiff Seppo Salko in the pretrial investigation before the court case ''Prosecutor v. Ruokanen''. Espoo Police, 19 May 2002.</ref>) is a [[Finland|Finnish]] retired [[elementary school]] [[teacher]] and a former [[missionary]] to [[Taiwan]] with the [[Finnish Missionary Society]] (FMS), and together with his wife the longest serving employee of the FMS [[The Finnish dormitory in Taichung|dormitory in Taichung, Taiwan]].
==Education== Salko went to school in [[Lappeenranta]], [[Finland]]. During his early years there he became acquainted and friends with [[Sakari Pinola]], who later recruited him to missionary work in Taiwan. Salko has said he “grew up together” with Pinola.<ref name = Esitutkintapoytakirja />
During his years at school, Salko was such a [[piety|pious]] man that his classmates called him “pastor”. He participated in the Lappeenranta parish youth group of mission friends.<ref name = "17+7">{{cite journal | last = | title =Leikkisät 17+7. Lähetyskurssi 1970 |trans-title = ‘The playful 17+7. Mission candidates of 1970’ | journal =[[Suomen Lähetyssanomat]] | year =1970 | issue =9 | pages =258–260 | location = | publisher = The Finnish Missionary Society | id = | accessdate = | language = fi | lopetusmerkki = }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url =http://www.perttila.fi/Koulumuistoja/Koulumuistoja.htm | title =Non vitae sed scholae didicimus | last =Ilpo Perttilä | id = | journal = | year = | location = | publisher = | accessdate = | language = fi }}</ref> He did not go to [[high school]], but instead studied to become a teacher in the [[Heinola Seminary]], where he met his wife to be, Marja-Liisa Raulamo, who came from Tampere. Salko graduated in 1964, and Raulamo the following year.<ref name = "17+7" /><ref>{{cite book | last =Antero Valtasaari (editor) | title =Heinolan seminaari 1899–1972 |trans-title = ‘The Heinola Seminary 1899–1972’ | year =1972 | page =187 | pages = | id = | location =Heinola | publisher = | isbn = | url = | www-teksti = | accessdate = | language = fi }}</ref> It appears that the Salkos got married in 1965. Part of the engagement was a pledge to go out as missionaries.<ref name = "17+7" />
==Work in Finland == The next five years the Salkos worked as teachers in [[Ristijärvi]] in the [[Kainuu]] province. During that time they furthered the missionary cause in the parish. Salko reported in the FMS magazine ''[[Suomen Lähetyssanomat]]'' in 1970 of a lunch that was arranged as a fundraiser, which had yielded more than 3000 [[Finnish mark]]s for mission work. After the five years in Ristijärvi, the Salkos found themselves in 1970 in the mission candidates’ course with the FMS in [[Helsinki]].<ref name = "17+7" /><ref>{{cite journal | last =Seppo Salko | title =Lähetyslounas Ristijärvellä | journal =Suomen Lähetyssanomat |trans-title = ‘Mission lunch in Ristijärvi’ | year =1970 | issue =1 | pages =11 | location = | publisher = The Finnish Missionary Society | id = | accessdate = | language = fi | lopetusmerkki = }}</ref>
==Work as a missionary in Taiwan== The Salkos left from Finland to [[Taiwan]] on 19 October 1971.<ref>{{cite journal | last = | title =Kuulumisia |trans-title = ‘Informal news’ | journal =Suomen Lähetyssanomat | year =1971 | volume = | issue =11 | pages = 258 | location =Helsinki | publisher = Suomen Lähetysseura | id = | accessdate = | language = fi | lopetusmerkki = }}</ref> Their first term as missionaries in Taiwan lasted from 1971 to 1975.<ref>Ijäs 1987, s. 37–38.</ref><ref>{{cite book |title= Suomen Lähetysseuran vuosikirja 1974 |trans-title = ‘Yearbook of the Finnish Missionary Society 1974’ | id = |last= |first= |authorlink= |year= 1974 |publisher= |location= Joensuu |isbn= |page= 88 |pages= |accessdate= |url= }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title= Me kaukana ja lähellä. Suomen Lähetysseuran vuosikirja 1975 |trans-title = ‘We far and near. Yearbook of the Finnish Missionary Society 1975’ | id = |last= Tauno Väinölä (ed.) |first= |authorlink= |year= 1975 |publisher= |location= Joensuu |isbn= |page= 150 |pages= |accessdate= |url= }}</ref><ref name=Aitomiehet>{{cite web| url = http://aitomiehet.net/material/kulltorp/herran_kukkaro.pdf | title = Aitomiehet ja katulapset | last =Mikko Ollilainen | id = | journal =Aitomiehet, Herran kukkaro | year = | location = | publisher = Aitomiehet — Kristillinen miestenpiiri | accessdate = | language =}}</ref> They used their first year in Taiwan studying the local languages. After that they began their work in [[The Finnish dormitory in Taichung]], which at the time was operated in rented premises. The Finnish children attended [[Morrison Academy]], an [[United States|American]] school that functioned in [[Taichung]]. The distance from the children’s homes to the school was between 200 and 300 [[kilometers]].
Due to a change in the city plan, Morrison had to abandon its old campus and built a new one outside the city. At this stage, a separate building for the Finnish dormitory was built on the new campus. The planning of the dormitory building had many twists and turns, but in the end Seppo Salko had the final word in determining what the building was to be like.<ref>{{cite journal | last = | title =Lapsemme Taiwanissa |trans-title = ‘Our children in Taiwan’ | journal =Suomen Lähetyssanomat | year =1973 | volume = | issue = | pages =15 | location = | publisher = The Finnish Missionary Society | id = | accessdate = | language = fi }}</ref><ref>Ijäs 1987, p. 36–38.</ref>
In 1974, the Salkos wrote about their work as follows:<ref>{{cite journal | last =Seppo ja Marja-Liisa Salko | title =Suomalaislapsia |trans-title = ‘Finnish children ’ | journal = Suomen Lähetyssanomat | year = | volume = | issue =4/1974 | pages =15 | location = | publisher = The Finnish Missionary Society | id = | accessdate = | language = fi }}</ref>
{{cquote|Our new home offers better living quarters for our children, as well as a quiet atmosphere for studying and possibilities for leisure activities. Housekeeping, too, has become easier due to the more spacious and practical premises. A completely new thing to be glad about is the Finnish [[sauna]] that was built next to the main bathroom. The children’s playing room is so large that lessons can be arranged there. Even though the [[curriculum]] of the American school is mostly similar to those of Finnish schools, it is natural that they give weight to different subjects. The [[Finnish language]] and [[Finnish geography]] are subjects in which we must provide complementary instruction, so that the children will be prepared for their return to Finland.
All in all we believe that the Lord Himself has created this possibility before us and opened the gates for us. With the same costs we could never offer Finnish education of the same quality and diversity from preschool to ‘[[matriculation]]’.
Our new dormitory is an answer to many years of prayers. We, the ‘parents’, pray continually that this home could fulfill its task: to be such a good place to the children that their parents could safely and free of worries dedicate themselves to their proper work.}}
During the school year 1975–76, the Salkos had a [[furlough]] in Finland, and another missionary couple, Simo and Tarja Lipasti, ran the dormitory during that time.<ref>Ijäs 1987, p. 38.</ref>
The Salkos’ second term began in 1976 and ended in 1980,<ref>Ijäs 1987, p. 37–38.</ref><ref>{{cite book |title= Tulevaisuuden Aasia. Suomen Lähetysseuran vuosikirja 1977. |trans-title = ‘The Asia of the Future. Yearbook of the Finnish Missionary Society 1977’ | id = | last = Tauno Väinölä (ed.) |first= |authorlink= |year= 1977 |publisher= |location= |isbn= 951-624-163-8 |page= 148 |pages= |accessdate= |url= }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title= Oikeus evankeliumiin. Suomen Lähetysseuran vuosikirja 1978 |trans-title = ‘Right to the Gospel. Yearbook of the Finnish Missionary Society 1978’ | id = |last= Jouko Räty (ed.) |first= |authorlink= |year= 1978 |publisher= |location= |isbn= 951-624-167-0 |page= |pages= |accessdate= |url= }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title= Kastamalla ja opettamalla. Suomen Lähetysseuran vuosikirja 1979 |trans-title = ‘By Baptizing and Teaching. Yearbook of the Finnish Missionary Society 1979’ | id = |last= Jouko Räty (ed.) |first= |authorlink= |year= 1979 |publisher= |location= Helsinki |isbn= 951-624-168-9 |page= 155 |pages= |accessdate= |url= }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title= Jumalan koulussa. Suomen Lähetysseuran vuosikirja 1980 |trans-title = ‘In God’s School. Yearbook of the Finnish Missionary Society 1980’ | id = |last= Kyllikki Valtonen (ed.) |first= |authorlink= |year= 1980 |publisher= |location= Helsinki |isbn=951-624-172-7 |page= 134 |pages= |accessdate= |url= }}</ref> and the third term lasted from 1981 to 1985.<ref name=Aitomiehet /><ref>{{cite book |title= Jumalan käytössä. Suomen Lähetysseuran vuosikirja 1982 |trans-title = ‘In God’s Use. Yearbook of the Finnish Missionary Society 1982’ | id = |last= Mirja Poutanen (ed.) |first= |authorlink= |year= 1982 |publisher= |location= Helsinki |isbn= 951-624-174-3 |page= 106 |pages= |accessdate= |url= }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title= Kaikkeen maailmaan. Suomen Lähetysseuran vuosikirja 1983 |trans-title = ‘Into the Wide World. Yearbook of the Finnish Missionary Society’ | issn = 0781-6162 |last= Mirja Poutanen (ed.) |first= |authorlink= |year= 1983 |publisher= |location= Helsinki |isbn= |page= 113 |pages= |accessdate= |url= }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title= Kristus lähettää. Suomen Lähetysseura 125 vuotta 1859–1984 |trans-title = ‘Christ Sends. The Finnish Missionary Society 125 Years 1859–1984’ | issn = 0781-6162 |last= Mirja Poutanen (ed.) |first= |authorlink= |year= |publisher= |location= Helsinki |isbn= 951-624-177-8 |page= 126 |pages= |accessdate= |url= }}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last = Leena Suominen (ed.) | title =Kristus auttaa. Suomen Lähetysseuran vuosikirja 1985 |trans-title = ‘Christ helps. Yearbook of the Finnish Missionary Society 1985’ | year =1985 | page = | pages =137 | issn = 0781-6162 | location =Helsinki | publisher = The Finnish Missionary Society | accessdate = | language = fi }}</ref>
During the furloughs, Salko worked in the FMS headquarters in [[Helsinki]]. During 1975–76 he was responsible for the circulation of the FMS magazine ''[[Suomen Lähetyssanomat]]''<ref>{{cite journal | last = | title = Staff | journal = Suomen Lähetyssanomat | year =1976 | volume = | issue =1 | pages =2 | location = | publisher = Suomen Lähetysseura | id = | url = | accessdate = | language = fi }}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last = | title =Vastauksemme: Lähetys. Suomen Lähetysseuran vuosikirja 1976 |trans-title = ‘Our Answer: Mission. Yearbook of the Finnish Missionary Society 1976’ | year =1976 | page =154 | pages = | id = | location =Helsinki | publisher = The Finnish Missionary Society | isbn = | url = | accessdate = | language = fi }}</ref> and during 1980–81 he worked as the head of the audiovisual productions.<ref>{{cite book | last = | title =Hyvä sanoma kaikille. Suomen Lähetysseuran vuosikirja 1981 |trans-title = ‘The Good Message to All. Yearbook of the Finnish Missionary Society 1981’ | year =1981 | page =174 | pages = | id = | location =Helsinki | publisher = The Finnish Missionary Society | isbn =951-624-173-5 | url = | accessdate = | language = }}</ref>
After the Salkos’ third term, the FMS decided in 1985 that no one would be allowed to work at the Taichung dormitory for more than two terms.<ref>Ijäs 1987, p. 37.</ref> Thus, in 1985 the Salkos remained in Finland.
During 1985–87 Salko worked in the FMS as the person in charge of matters dealing with scholarship students in Finland,<ref>{{cite journal | last = Leena Suominen (ed.) | title = Vetten yli. |trans-title = ‘Across the Waters. Suomen Lähetysseuran vuosikirja 1986’ | journal = | year =1986 | volume = | issue = | pages =153 | location = Helsinki | publisher = Suomen Lähetysseura | issn = 0781-6162 | url = | www-teksti = | accessdate = | language = fi }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last = | title = Pirre Saario (ed.) | journal = Sytytä liekkisi. Yearbook of the Finnish Missionary Society 1987 | year =1987 | volume = | issue = | pages =147 | location = Helsinki | publisher = Suomen Lähetysseura | issn = 0781-6162 | accessdate = | language = fi }}</ref> until the FMS reversed its decision on the “two terms” rule at the dormitory and sent the Salkos for a fourth term during 1987–91.<ref>{{cite book |title= Tule katso mene kerro. Suomen Lähetysseuran vuosikirja 1988 |trans-title = Come See Go Tell. Yearbook of the Finnish Missionary Society 1988 |issn = 0781-6162 |last= Pirre Saario (ed.) |first= |authorlink= |year= 1988 |publisher= |location= Helsinki |isbn= |page= 151 |pages= |accessdate= |url= }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title= Ilo tulee kaupunkiin. Suomen Lähetysseuran vuosikirja 1989 |trans-title = ‘Joy Comes to Town. Yearbook of the Finnish Missionary Society 1989’ |issn = 0781-6162 |last= Pirre Saario (ed.) |first= |authorlink= |year= 1989 |publisher= |location= Helsinki |isbn= |page= |pages= |accessdate= |url= }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title= Suomen Lähetysseuran vuosikirja 1990 |trans-title = ‘Yearbook of the Finnish Missionary Society 1990’ |issn = 0781-6162 |last= Pirre Saario (ed.) |first= |authorlink= |year= 1990 |publisher= |location= |isbn= |page= 137 |pages= |accessdate= |url= }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title= Suomen Lähetysseuran vuosikirja 1991 |trans-title = ‘Yearbook of the Finnish Missionary Society 1991’ |issn = 0781-6162 |last= Tuulikki Vilhunen (ed.) |first= |authorlink= |year= 1991 |publisher= |location= Jyväskylä |isbn= |page= 163 |pages= |accessdate= |url= }}</ref>
==Working in Finland 1991–95== The Salkos returned to Finland for good in 1991. After this, Salko worked with the FMS, assigned to the [[Lapua Diocese]]<ref name =Vilhunen180>{{cite book |title= Suomen Lähetysseuran vuosikirja 1992 |trans-title = ‘Yearbook of the Finnish Missionary Society 1992.’ |issn = 0781-6162 |last= Tuulikki Vilhunen (ed.) |first= |authorlink= |year= 1992 |publisher= |location= |isbn= |page= 229 |pages= |accessdate= |url= }}</ref> and after this during 1992–95 as the person responsible for the functioning of the [[Mission Church (Helsinki)|FMS Mission Church]] at the FMS headquarters in Helsinki.<ref>{{cite book |title= Suomen Lähetysseuran
